item.description:
In Little Town Builders, you lead a team of architects and must dispatch workers to the town, collect resources and money, build buildings, and develop this little town.

In the game, which lasts four rounds, you can acquire resources such as wood, stones, fish, and wheat from the surrounding squares by putting workers on the board, with three workers being placed each round. When you place a worker, you acquire the resources available in all eight surrounding spaces. You can build buildings by using these resources, and you — or any other player — can gain the effect of the building when place a worker next to it; if you place next to a building owned by another, however, you must pay them a coin before you can collect those resources.

Players collect victory points by using the powers of buildings, by constructing buildings, and by achieving goals dealt to them at the beginning of the game. After four rounds, whoever has the most victory points wins.

—description from the publisher

Adorable Monsters is the super cute card game, for all ages, in which the first player to put together a squad of 7 cutie patootie monsters, wins! Have a blast with your buds, pals, mates, friends, family, or even absolute strangers, as you try to be the first to create your monster squad!

How to Play
Learning to play Adorable Monsters is easy! That's because what each card can be used to do during play is written directly on it, in the form of concise instructions.

To begin the game, all players draw 5 cards and thereafter take turns drawing and playing one card at a time, as they try to line up a squad of 7 monsters in front of them to win the game.

Of course, it's not that easy, as there are lots of cards that players can use to remove monsters from their opponents' squads. So, not only do you have to try to put together your monster squad, but you have to try to stop your friends from doing so, too!

—description from the publisher

link.value: Adorable Monsters: The Super Freaking Awesome Expansion Pack

item.description:
With a unique cast of characters with special powers from the Eisner Award-nominated comic series, you and up to seven friends play as a gang of shifty shady felines trying to keep their speakeasy afloat.

The game is cooperative with all players loading into their car, the Fordor, and exploring a randomly arranged deck of location cards laid out face down on the table. Players must get enough of "The Good Stuff" back to the Lackadaisy Speakeasy before the time runs out and the speakeasy folds like a cheap suit. Players will need to arm themselves and use the special location powers to their best ability to win. With event cards that can help as much as harm, the tide of the game can turn at any moment.

item.description:
455 CARDS OF “SNOT-OUT-OF-YOUR-NOSE” LAUGHTER!

Not Parent Approved is a kid-friendly word game of fill-in-the-blanks inspired by Cards Against Humanity. This game was created to provide an attention-grabbing, easy-to learn and hilarious alternative to screen time for children and their families.

A brilliant screen zombie antidote that’s effortless fun at a kids slumber party or Thanksgiving Dinner with Grandma. Bring back the joy of face-to-face engagement and see your kid’s eyeballs again. What a concept!


 Gameplay is simple - It’s Mad Libs gone Bad Libs! Each round, one player picks and reads a question card and everyone else answers with the funniest answer card.
 Not Parent Approved gives kids a feeling of being naughty and cool but within (most) parental boundaries.
 Not Parent Approved makes it okay to put vampire bunnies,


fart, and Grandma in the same sentence!

—description from the publisher

name.value: Roads and Rails, Rivers and Trails

item.description: Play your cards to build a shared network of roads, rails, rivers, and trails. Block your opponents while scoring paths for yourself -- but don't forget about any of your own paths, or you'll be caught short at the end!

Owen's Chase is an asymmetrical 2-player deduction game set in the 19th century Nantucket. Whales are trying to safely travel north to the feeding grounds to feast on rich krill while being pursued by a sharp lookout in the crow's nest of a whaling ship. On each expedition, use your senses to track down a whale in the vast ocean. But be careful of dangerous weather, unexpected repairs, or even a nasty tail fluke that can bring your chase quickly to an end.

One player plays as the Whale and the other as the Lookout. The Whale player puts the cards face down in a 4 x 4 grid, and the Lookout chooses cards. Based on the card chosen when revealed, various actions occur that can have the Lookout win, the Whale win, or other results. Play continues until the Whale is found or or the Shipyard is found, or until the expedition ends. Cards include the Whale, a tail attack, crow's nest, open ocean, shipyard, and storm.

—user summary

The war had raged for millennia. Or it started just a week ago, depending on how you look at it. Time travel can be quite confusing. What's known for certain is that the fighting is between four different sides: The Aliens, the Apes and Monkeys, the Robots, and the Space Vikings. They all got access to the temporal technologies at the same time, not that "same time" means much in this situation. With time travel it doesn't really matter *when* it's invented...

Each player is sending out their agents to different points in the timestream, trying to control key time periods and technologies. By planning your moves right you can re-use the same cards multiple times, and even revive agents killed in action!

Time War(p) is a quick card game for two to four players ages 13 and up.

—description from the publisher

item.description:
The time has come to prepare for battle, as Upper Deck Entertainment Introduces World of Warcraft "Drums of War- PVP Battle Decks

The thundering drums of war echo throughout the land of Kalimdor. New warlords ride through the gates of Orgrimmar, eager to serve the warchief and leave their marks on the pages of history.
Small battalions of Alliance soldiers arrive at outposts throughout Azeroth.
They solidify their footholds in contested areas as marshals draw up strategies to defend their territories and press any aggressors who foolishly cross their paths.
It is only a matter of time until the piercing battle cries, roaring magic, and crashing steel evoke the symphony of war once again.

When the dust settles, will you be remembered, or will you fade into oblivion?

Call to Arms!

—description from the publisher

link.value: World of Warcraft Trading Card Game

name.value: A'Writhe: A Game of Eldritch Contortions

item.description:
Summon the Great Old Ones by having them align their bodies over Arkham.

In the game A'Writhe: A Game of Eldritch Contortions, players gather in teams of two. Each team consists of a cultist player and a Great Old One player. The cultist is assisting the Great Old One and attempting to summon them to our plane. To do this, the cultist instructs their deity, with great veneration, to place an appendage on top of an Arkham landmark to complete a specific pattern. The problem is that it is nigh impossible to have one Great Old One form this pattern by itself; that's why if another deity is touching any parts of your pattern, you can use that appendage to complete your own pattern!

Up to three teams of two can play in this contortionist battle of positioning.

—description from the publisher

item.description:
Each round, players write words on their whiteboards using the available letter cards, but they score points only for the cards they are able to claim before their opponents — and words score only if the player follows the ever-changing rules.

The player who scores the most points at the end of five rounds wins.

—description from the publisher

item.description:
Travel around the most beautiful places in XVIth century Europe with Montaigne!
In 1580 and 1581, Michel de Montaigne is travelling Europe on horseback. In a Travel journal, he writes of this extraordinary experience.
Become travelers and follow his steps around France, Germany, Switzerland or Italy, to discover countries through Montaigne’s eyes, meet people he encountered and think with his mind… Until King Henri III calls you back to Bordeaux, as he did with Montaigne asking him to become the city’s mayor, then you will have to end your journey and go back to the South West of France as fast as you can.

This is a multi-purpose card game for 2 to 4 players from 8 years old.
The players manage their best hand cards they will pose in front of them, deploying the many discoveries of their trip (gastronomy, meetings, visits or reading the Montaigne books ...), while observing the choices of other players.
Voyages avec Montaigne offers many mechanics interlaced in a simple and fluid way. Opportunism, interaction and anticipation make the pleasure of a game that suddenly makes one of the greatest French writers of all time very close.

In the game Voyages avec Montaigne, players place cards face up next to the last card they placed, on a line from left to right. This line represents their journey.

On their turn, players take turns with 1 action among 3 : 

 Travel : place a card from a different city AND pay the cost of the travel (0, 1 or 2 cards discarded)
 Stay : placing a card of the same city AND pick 1 new card
 Get supplies : not placing a card AND pick and 2 new cards




Players can discard a figure met during his journey to take another action OR take a card from the discard pile.

2 travelling rules must be respected :

 At the end of their journey, players must return to Bordeaux and have placed at least on « Citation » card form each of the 3 books of Montaigne
 Players cannot go back to a city they have already been.




During their journey, players take one of the Bonus tile available as soon as they reach the objective first or do better than a player who had already achieved the objective (5 discovery bonus, 4 book bonus).

When the « King’s call » special card is revealed, all players must go back to Bordeaux as soon as possible, rules are thus modified :

 Action « Stay » is not allowed anymore
 Players cannot travel to a city that would take them further away from Bordeaux.




First players returning to Bordeaux get bonus, As soon as all players but one have returned to Bordeaux, the last player only has one turn left to play.

Bonus tiles are awarded to players : most cities visited, the most different theme cards, the most different characters encountered, largest stay.

The player with the highest score wins.

Players try to win elections by playing cards. At the beginning, two dice are thrown and multiplied by ten thousand to know how many votes must be obtained to win.

Players then place positive cards in front, and opponents can place negative cards in front of others. Each of the five different positive cards allows you to start a stack.

A player can not have more than one stack of the same quality.

If you are blocked in a stack, you can unlock it with a positive card of the same type.

According to the stacks that you have unlocked you can place votes in front of you. These do not count how one of the stacks allowed.

There are televised debates that begin with a card, and that are resolved by rolling a dice each opponent and adding their unblocked stacks.

Win the first to get the necessary votes.

—user summary

You built and defended your kingdom, and now that winter is here, you need to battle the harsh elements and chillingly scary monsters.

Dwar7s Winter is a hand-building, resource management game with tower defense elements in the gameplay. Each player wants to achieve more victory points, but the only way to survive the winter is to work together.

While Dwar7s Winter is a sequel to Dwar7s Fall, it is an independent, standalone game that includes 64 highly-detailed miniatures.

item.description:
What: Wargame/RPG rules for World War II. 
Scale: Man to man combat. 1 figure equals 1 man; 1 model equals 1 vehicle.
Your Role: Players can command from one squad to a platoon of infantry or from one platoon to a company of tanks.
Playability: Designed for solo, same side and head to head play.

NUTS can be played in a variety of ways:

You can play as a Squad Leader with a full squad.
You can play as a Squad Leader with less than a full squad.
You can play as a Fighting Vehicle Platoon Leader with three to five vehicles.
You can play with only one Fighting Vehicle.
You can play large games with multiple squads and vehicles.

The bottom line is you can play it any way you like, with any figures or counters you like.

Inside you’ll find:


 Rules for infantry combat with over 15 different formations.
 Rules for vehicle combat with stats for over 100 types.
 Four armies to choose from – American, British, German and Russian.
 Thirty-five unique attributes to personalize your squad members.
 Rules for urban combat.
 A minimal bookkeeping Campaign System that gives meaning to every game as the results of one will affect the outcome of the next.

You are invited to a Killer Dinner! However, this is no ordinary dinner party. Everyone is masked and has their own hidden agenda. Who is your friend, and who is planning on stabbing you tonight?
Ask questions, collect items, and attack other partygoers to accomplish your hidden agenda before anyone else. Blend in while figuring out your fellow partygoers’ hidden agendas before it’s too late!

At the beginning of the game each player gets a card with their secret role and hidden agenda. Attending the party are The Host, The BFF, The Trickster, and The Hitman. Everyone, except the Hitman, is also informed of the Host’s profession on their Role Card. 
The Host’s agenda is to figure out who the Hitman is and to kill them. 
The BFF’s agenda is to help and protect the Host. 
The Trickster’s agenda is to attack or get attacked a total of seven times. 
The Hitman’s agenda is to figure out the Host’s profession, or to kill them.
While in the same room, players may ask each other yes/no questions to discern information about the Host’s profession, revealing who the Hitman is based on incorrect answers. Players explore the house and collect items upon entering an empty room. Items can be used to help gather information, attack other players, or replenish lost Health.
Whoever accomplishes their hidden agenda first, wins the game.

Killer Dinner is a party game that will create a new social dynamic each time it’s played. A great number of Host’s professions and the random role allocation, makes every game different. Due to the social aspect and asking questions the game is a good opportunity to get to know your fellows players better!

—description from the designers

Prime Number Five is very easy mathmatic memory game.
Contain 30 cards.
All cards has frontside number and backside number.
Each card, frontside and backside has a some relation.

Backside numbers are 2, 3, 5, 7, and 11. (5 types number x 6 cards)
Frontside numbers are 4, 6, 9, 10, 14, 15, 21, 22, 25, 33, 35, 49, 55, 77, and 121. (15 types number x 2 cards)

If frontside number is 14, then the card's backside is 2 or 7.
Because 14=2x7
If backside number is 3, then the card's frontside is 6, 9, 15, 21, or 33.

Shuffle all cards, and spread them on table.
In your turn, reveal one card and another.
If the two cards's frontside numbers are same, you get it.
Get, or not get, next player's turn.

—description from the publisher

Dry Bones is a card based game where you play as a traveler in the desert, trying to solve the mistery of the prophet Yejez.Qe'l and the dry bones to revive them.

You will have to deal with storms, collect items, open seals, complete misions and many more.

The charm of the game are the musical cards that make you listen to a fragment of a song and then answer a question about it. The music is original and provided by the creator herself.

—description from the designer

The game consists of a board based on a railway map of Switzerland, and around 100 cardboard tokens labeled with the names of each station.

The object is to be the first player to complete a pre-agreed journey across the map by rolling a die and moving. A six gets another turn but if a second six is rolled then the player must move backwards. Mountain and local lines can only be traversed when the correct number is thrown.

The rules sheet (bilingual German/French) give 10 different variants for how the players' routes may be chosen: in some the tokens are placed on the map and collected, in others the tokens are used to draw a station at random.

Publisher: Papa Schubi â„– 2822.

The throne has remained vacant for far too long, the Bloodstone’s power has begun to wane, Monstrosities assault the city, and the people have become desperate. You have travelled far to arrive in the city of Bloodstone. The desperate situation in the city means it is finally time for a new Ruler to be chosen. You have five days to gain the favour of the people and they are eager to be impressed.
 Your paths to victory are numerous: use subterfuge and guile to gain the support of some of the city’s most influential citizens, all while slaying Monstrosities that appear each night; amass great wealth and purchase symbols of status to impress the masses; specialize in defeating the Monstrosities, wherever they may appear, and harvest them for the riches that lay within. Although eager to be impressed, the citizens of Bloodstone are fickle and each day they demand new displays of wealth and power. Plan ahead so your strategy will meet these demands each day.
 You are not the only hero to see this as their opportunity. Others have journeyed to the city and will fight to impede your progress at every turn. Can you win the favour of the citizens, ascend the Vacant Throne, and restore power to the Bloodstone?

Descendants: Realm's Rift is a deep strategy game with immense replayability. In fact, no two games will ever be the same.

Players can all play with the same faction abilities by using Side A of the player board, or each player can choose to play as a unique faction and unlock special abilities and Rages. Play as a Warlock, Earth Elemental, Giant, or one of the other unique factions.

Throughout 5 days, players will track their time using a unique and intuitive time track. This track consists of 24 spaces. Each player begins with 12 time before the Midnight Oil ends their day, but through upgrades it is possible to improve Ambition and start the day with more time. Each movement through the city and actions at a building costs time, so plan your route and day wisely. Whoever has the most time remaining in the day will always play next - so player order is dynamic. Once you enter the Midnight Oil your day will end.

Players move their characters throughout the game board using a one-of-a-kind worker placement mechanic. Your hero blocks building action spaces. When you move, the building action space becomes available. Each game includes 9/15 buildings (6 consistent, 3 random). Depending on your strategy and immediate needs you may want to visit the Butcher to gain Bloodstones, or the Blacksmith to buy gear. You may wish to travel to the Market to make some important trades, or maybe you need to visit the Grand Palace to submit your rumors. During all of this, your hero is also tasked with slaying the monstrosities that lurk at buildings and collecting rumors. These rumors point to one of four suspects - Queen, Grand Magus, Executioner, Apothecary. The more rumors you gather and influence you use the more resources and Favour Points you will earn on the suspect track. But remember, rumors don't come cheap.

Each day players will try to improve their engine to maximize the income at Day's End. They do this by unlocking dormant cubes and visiting the Philosopher's Study for upgrades. Spend the Bloodstones you have collected from slaying monstrosities to upgrade your hero. Some upgrade examples are: Income (silver, gold, energy regeneration, etc.), Ambition (more time), Network of Spies (unlocks higher levels on the suspect track), and special faction abilities.

Players must be aware of the Leadership Goals in order to also maximize daily Favour Points. Which actions you take and which rumors you play will often be affected by the strategy you devise at the start of the game according to the Leadership Goals in play.

At the end of the game players will score points based on their Gear, Wealth, Upgrades, Strength, and Success on the Suspect Track.

Can you be the next Ruler of Bloodstone?

This is the 7th in a series of Annual Games Unlimited Holiday Games and is the followup to Gameshop Express (2011), Gameshop Workday (2012), Gameshop Gladiators (2013), Gameshop Adventurers (2014), Gameshop Expansions (2015), and Gameshop Collector (2016).

The Mirror Universe employees of Unlimited Games have come to our reality to battle gurus Kylie, Candra and Andrew for control over the Games Unlimited store. Only one game team will reign supreme!

To Win: Place all your active Guru markers (any remaining on the board) on any of the gray marked spaces in your opponent’s home row or remove all of your opponent’s markers.

Setup: Place the board between players and orient it so that one player is facing the 3 Games Unlimited Gurus and the other player their mirror duplicate Gurus from Unlimited Games. The row closest to the player is their home row. Each player receives 
3 Guru markers in a matching color. Place these markers, 
1 each, on the 3 gray spaces on your home row. Shuffle the 
4 Action cards and, without looking at them, flip half the cards over to their opposite side. Deal 1 card face up in front of each player and place 1 card to the side of the board. The 4th card is removed from the game. The first player will be the one who has most recently looked in a mirror.

Play: Each player has an Action card that displays a possible move for any of their markers. There is a 3rd card to one side of the board that cannot be used by either player during their turn. On a player’s turn, they move 1 of their active Guru markers (Note: Active Guru markers are the ones remaining on the board) according to the Action card; they then replace the card they used with the 3rd card. The other player then moves accordingly, and exchanges their card with this new 3rd card - the card the first player just used.
Moving a marker on top of one of an opponent player’s markers removes that opponent’s marker from the game.

A player may stack a maximum of 2 of their pieces on any space except the center space. A stack prevents either stacked piece from being captured.

Moving your active Guru markers to the home row spaces of 
your opponent wins you the game.

As long as one of a player’s markers remains on the center space on the board, that player may, during their turn, flip their Action card over to its opposite face to introduce a new move into the game.

Action cards should be oriented with the name of the action at the bottom of the card. Each card shows the player’s marker in the middle of the card and indicates which spaces, either forward, backward or to the side, to which they may move their marker. Below this diagram, the action on the other face of the card is displayed.

—description from the publisher

“You are not breach mages yet,” Brama lectures as she paces down the line of students, her frail form belying her immense power. “Breach mages have protected us since the beginning — since the burning of the world and our pilgrimage into the dark. It was they who founded Gravehold, our last bastion, and if you wish to stand beside these living legends, you must listen and learn. The Nameless shall come again, as they always have, and you will need to be ready. You are the hope of our future.”

As a young apprentice, you grew up to stories of the breach mages. Brama, the teacher, wisest of the mages. Dezmodia, the prodigy, master of great magic. Mist, the stoic leader and tactical genius. Malastar, the magical craftsman. Rebellious, powerful, and reckless perfectly sum up Xaxos. These mages are your heroes and tomorrow, after your ordeal, you will join their ranks.

“Each of you must overcome your ordeal to learn discipline and focus, the tools you will need to defend Gravehold. We are nothing without Gravehold. To be a breach mage is to sacrifice your life for Gravehold. When you die, it will be in defense of our city. Once you understand this universal truth...only then will you be ready to become a breach mage.”

Aeon's End is not required to play Aeon's End: Legacy.

item.description:
Cthulhu: XOTHIC WARS is the master rules set for a new 28mm Monster Skirmish Game. It is based around the Aliens of the HP Lovecraft mythos, and will cover all main 7 species.

The premise is the wars fought on Earth before the rise of mankind. Each core box in the wave will be complimented by a separate campaign book. It is flexible enough to include use for play in eras with man where the Aliens were also present.

The miniatures will start with the Starspawn of Cthulhu, as they engage the Elder Things for domination of the newly formed planet. We want these miniatures for ourselves, so will be sculpting and printing all of the races regardless. So the Mi-Go and the rest are in the pipeline.

Miniatures will include resin masters for collectors, and are done in 28mm for most popular ranges. Additionally they scale nicely for 15mm and 6mm gamers.

—description from the publisher

item.description:
What lies beneath the crumbling walls of Karak castle? A labyrinth full of treasures... and monsters! Six brave adventurers are going in there for a fortune waiting to be claimed, each one of them with a different trick up their sleeve. But the treasure chests are locked and monsters are everywhere. Who will outsmart their opponents, beat the monsters and seize the dragon’s gem?

In Karak each player will lead one of the six different characters to the labyrinth of Karak. Tile by tile, they’ll uncover what the labyrinth looks like – it will be different in each playthrough. They’ll have to fight with monsters, equip with weapons and spells, and most importantly – collect treasure. The player with the most treasure at the end of the game is the winner – a true champion of Karak!


 What’s in the box: approx. 80 cardboard labyrinth tiles; approx. 30 cardboard monster tokens; approx. 30 cardboard item tokens; 5 cardboard hero sheets; 6 cardboard hero portraits; 6 cardboard hero pawns; 2 dice; rulebook
 Fast-paced family RPG
 Simple rules
 Different characters allow different approaches
 Great artwork


—description from the publisher

item.description:
In Kiwara, two groups of animals compete for space in the savanna, claiming points when they dominate a territory, but the value of a space depends on who's in it!

The game board features six territories — two each of three, five, and seven spaces — with rivers dividing all of the territories. Each player has fifteen animals tokens in their color. One player places the totem on a space outside the 6x5 board, then players alternate taking turns. On a turn, a player:

• Places one of their animal tokens in an empty space in the row or column adjacent to the totem.
• Moves the totem 1-3 spaces clockwise. (If all spaces in these rows or columns are full, the player moves the totem to the first row with an empty space.)

If a lion is placed orthogonally adjacent to zebras or gazelles, then the zebras are turned face down (yum!) while the gazelles are returned to their owners. If a player must place a zebra or gazelle adjacent to a lion, these tokens are placed face down.

If you place a crocodile across the river from a gazelle, you can exchange these tokens. (The crocodile attacks, and the gazelle bounds to safety.) You can swap the location of a crocodile many times this way.

Whoever places the token that fills the first savanna claims the Okapi card, which is worth 5 points at game's end. Once the board is filled, determine who has the most tokens in each territory; face-down tokens are counted to determine majority. Whoever wins a territory scores points equal to the value of all face-up animals in this territory: zebras 6, gazelles 2, elephants 5, lions 1, and crocodiles 0. Whoever has the most points wins!

While the base game of Kiwara is the same as the earlier Drôles de Zèbres, the game includes a double-sided game board. If you use the "free play" side of the board, to set up you use the river sticks included to create six territories of sizes 3, 5, 7 or 9, thereby creating a fresh layout for each game.

Instead of using the Okapi, you can shuffle the ten-card reinforcement deck and give the player who completes the first savanna a random card; the player can use the bonus action on this card at any point during the game. With players of differing skills, the more inexperienced player can start with a card or two at random to level the odds.

item.description:
"But, but...who did that?!"

In the card game Who Did It?, players race to get rid of their cards so that they can avoid the blame of owning the animal that pooped. Each game is as fun as it is fast; quickly find your card, be the first to throw it down, then blame someone else! Was it YOUR cat that pooped in the living room? Because it sure wasn't my bunny!

—description from the publisher

link.value: Who did it?: Kangaroo Promo Cards

item.description: It's time for a race! Can you make a face faster than anyone else in Cubeez? Not on your own face, though; no, you need to quickly turn and flip your three cubes to match the silly face on the challenge card. Will your Cubeez be surprised, sad, happy, angry, or a little bit of everything?

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description: Catan: Chocolate Edition is a simplified version of Catan in which all the resources are made of chocolate!

Top Deer is a race game in which 2-4 players try and breed and race the best reindeer for Santa's sleigh team.

The chief stablemaster at Santa's North Pole lair has announced his upcoming retirement, and Santa is holding a contest to decide who to promote. Whoever can win the most races - or most-accurately pick the fastest reindeer most consistently - will get the top job, but there are a number of less-than-nice-list tactics your opponents might employ to bump your career off the track!

Each reindeer is represented by a hand of five regular French-deck playing cards. In each race player stack these cards in a pre-determined order and turn them over to move their reindeer around the track; after each race players have a chance to selectively breed the best traits from their current reindeer into the next generation of racers.

Top Deer is a single-sheet game that doesn't need any construction and just requires a few tokens per player and a couple of decks of cards, intended to be included in a Christmas card.

—description from the publisher
Monopoly with Sonic the Hedgehog.

10193 AG – The drug spice melange is the most precious substance in the known universe, enabling humans to achieve great mental feats. It can only be found on the planet Arrakis, commonly referred to as Dune, its profitable harvesting operations administered by the Great House Atreides.

After a treacherous sneak attack by the Padishah Emperor and House Harkonnen, the young Paul Atreides finds refuge with the indigenous Fremen who believe him to be their “Giver of Water”, a messianic off-world prophet destined to lead them out of darkness. The new Duke forms a massive army of Fremen fighters with the aim of fulfilling the prophecy, changing the course of humanity forever.

"DUNE: Struggle for Arrakis" is a two-player strategic war game depicting the insurgency known as the Arrakis revolt. The game builds upon Mark Simonitch's The U.S. Civil War (GMT), adding new twists like changeable terrain, heavy storms and sandworms – all with a simplified ruleset and a more manageable playtime. The game is non-profit and free to download and play.

—description from the designer

Kingdom 18 is an 18 card hand management game with hints of deck building. Players take the role of nobles attempting to build kingdoms either through diplomacy or force. The goal is to grab the highest point value lands and create the most powerful kingdom or take less valuable lands that offer you powerful actions later.

Players start with a hand of 4 cards, each with 2 possible actions. These can be different values of military might or political savvy, or they can be an assassin or a shield that can steal the values of other cards their opponents play.

Each turn players place 1 card facedown on each land. These cards are revealed and another turn commences. After the second turn the players with the most strength on the land wins it. Bonus points are awarded for matching the types of cards the land prefers.

Collected lands count towards the end of the game scoring but also have their own in-game action. They are shuffled into the player's starting 4 cards and 4 new cards are drawn. The lands can have strong or weak abilities but only have one option.

Once all lands have been claimed the final scores are tallied and the highest score is the winner.

—description from the publisher

Itty Bitty Dungeon Delve is an 18 card tableau manipulation for 2 players. Each player represents a new adventurer exploring the cavernous rooms of a dungeon. Each is looking to gain experience and reach level 5 first, and they do so by rearranging the cards representing each individual cavern in the dungeon.

Players reveal cards from their cavern to rearrange facedown cards or gain knowledge of what the cards may be. At the end of the round they gain experience equal points from their cavern. If a player ends the turn with "The Smiter" card, they may instead choose another cavern to explore.

The first player to reach Level 5 wins!

—description from the designer

Sengoku: Warring States is an 18 card combat game. Players take the role of shoguns attempting to take out a rival with the use of their small army.

Over 3 phases players deploy 6 units to attack their opponents villages with the goal of destroying two villages, or the village containing their opponent's shogun. Doing so wins the player a battle. Soldiers remain facedown until the end of phase 3 or when an opposing soldier is placed down as well.

The first player to win two battles is victorious!

Contents:
18 Poker Cards
Folding Box/Rules

—description from the designer

It turns out that competition for flowers and the pollen that they produce has become fierce. Regular bees can't tack it. Killer bees can'd do it either. Who can? Ninja bees!

Your Ninja Bee starts in a Hive and has to wage a stealthy path through charted territory to a flower and back safely to the Hive. But beware, for other bees are looking for the same flowers and are not above sabotaging your mission - in fact they relish the chance.

Ninja Bees is a competitive card game for two or three players.
It is mentally challenging (meaning it will hurt your head).
It may ruin all of your friendships.
Includes 46 cards play cards and 2 instruction cards, all 3.25" x 3.75" hexagonal and in a beautiful box.

—description from the designer

name.value: Giant Ugly Flesh Monster Excavation Force

item.description:
Giant Ugly Flesh Monster Excavation Force (GUFMEF) is a 2-4 player cooperative game where players harvest precious resources from the rotting corpse of a gigantic monster in order to fulfill contracts for corporate resources. Navigate the corpse, communicate as a team, and gather resources, but beware, this is a high-risk position! As time progresses, the corpse rots and the body of the creature becomes unstable. It becomes the duty of the force to make sure that they not only complete their job in a timely manner but help every person on the team makes it out alive; liabilities are not good for corporate!

With different monsters and different contract types, each play experience becomes its own series of trials; but hopefully, with the use of tools and wits, the force will have what it takes to excavate exactly what they need. Gravity and time are your biggest foes but that is just another work day for the Giant Ugly Flesh Monster Excavation Force.

La bataille de Fleurus (8 messidor an II) deals with the battle fought on 26th June 1794 between a french army under the command of Jean-Baptiste Jourdan and a Coalition army (Austrians, Dutch, Hanovrians and even a legion of french émigrés, that is royalists) under the command of Prince of Coburg.

La bataille de Fleurus is the 3rd battle of the series Les Soldats de la République.

The game includes an A2 map, a color player aid and 216 counters and markers.

Bilingual Rules and Charts (English/French).

—description from the designer

Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
QUARDO is an exciting strategy game that challenges your planning, analytical, and pattern recognition abilities. In the “Touch of Quardo” advance game, the sense of touch, spatial coordination, and memorization skills are added to test players' spatial intelligence.

The objective of Quardo is to form multiple squares or lines of four pawns with a common attribute and to collect the associated tokens/coins. The player with the most number of tokens/coins wins.

With the addition of blindfolds for covering the eyes of ordinary players, Quardo is also designed to accommodate blind or vision-impaired players. Appoint an observer to administer the game if necessary.

—description from the designer

This is a light weight racing game for the light hearted. Racing around the track trying to get first over the finishing line as you are pumping up the steam in your engine and knocking out the others out of the way. But be aware that you will lose if you run out of fuel.

A kids and family racing game introducing resource management for younger players. Fuel the car engine to move, the more you feed the engine the faster it could go, but as hotter it gets.

Manage your resources and roll to move.

Bild your own racing tracks with the modular boards, customise your vehicles, manage the resources, nock the other cars out of track or try to break them and win the game.

Slogan: Racing for glory, win with luck and planing.

Theme: Car race

How to win: First to move over the finishing line of the final lap is the winner of the game.

Smart10 is a quiz game where a player doesn't need to wait for one's turn for long. 
There are ten possible answers to each question, and every player gets to answer every question. 
If the answer is correct, the player gets an answer marker. 
But should you answer or pass?
If you don't score your answer markers on time (and thereby pass on this round), you can end up losing them.
So if you are not 100% certain of an answer - do you gamble or do you pass?
Plays great in teams.

We Are The Word is a cooperative game in which one player tries to guess a word with the help of the other players, each giving him a one-word clue. But if two players come up with the same clue, they can't reveal it.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Introduction

Fugo is a drawless game for two players: Black and White. It's played on the intersections (points) of an initially empty square board. Each player must have access to a sufficient number of stones of their own color.

				
					Definitions

A group is a maximal set of orthogonally contiguous, like-colored stones.

A liberty is an empty point orthogonally adjacent to a group.

A smothered group is a group without liberties.

				
					Play

Black plays first, then turns alternate. At the start of your turn, you will face one of these situations:

a) There are no smothered friendly groups. In this case, you must place a stone of your color on an empty point. Your placement may not increase the number of smothered friendly groups unless it also increases the number of smothered enemy groups.

b) There are one or more smothered friendly groups. In this case, you must move one stone from one of those groups to an empty point such that, after the move, the group that now includes the moved stone has at least one liberty. You may only move a stone from a point where it's orthogonally adjacent to one or more enemy stones.

If you have no moves available on your turn, you lose.

				
					Pie rule

The pie rule is used in order to make the game fair. This means that White will have the option, on their first turn only, to change sides instead of making a regular move.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet

item.description:
BuzzPutt is a 1-4 player golf game that has you playing adorable bees! There are three pre-made putt putt courses that you and your friends can play on. Each person will select a bee and its matching ball. You have to place the ball on the starting point of the board, with the arrow pointing towards where you want to move.

Then, you roll the dice and pick a shot (basically a stroke in golf) based on what you have rolled. You can now move your ball that far. If you land on certain tiles, such as the honeycomb tiles, it'll cost you more movement points to move out. If you end up out of bounds, you must end your turn and start your next turn on the last tile you touched. Once everyone is at the end, you can move onto the next course.

—description from the designer

Pusher Kings is a funny, two-player card game that has you struggling to maintain control of the drug market in your town! This game is not a deck builder, so both players will be playing from a pre-set deck. Each player gets a hand of seven cards (with at least one "pusher" card in their hand) before the game starts. You must flip cards to use them, only using specific cards for your turn.

There are a few different card types; Pushers, Henchmen, and Actions. Pushers sell the drugs and can be used once per turn. Once you flip the card over in order to use them you gain money that can only be spent during that turn. Once the turn is over, the money disappears. Pushers cannot attack, defend, or take damage and only one can be used per turn.

Henchman have different costs, abilities, and attributes. They are used to gain power in the town and can be attacked. Henchman also cost a fair amount of money each, so you will need to be able to pay them to use them in your turn. The first turn you draw a henchman, you have to have them flipped, so they cannot be played right away.

Action cards are not flipped but instead discarded. There are only two of each action card in the deck, so you need to play them wisely. Each action is immediate and costs resources to play. These can be used to harm player’s henchmen or the player themselves.

Each player has 10 health points (the player themselves who holds the cards) so once they have been harmed enough to reach zero health points, the game is over.

Pusher Kings has some really awesome artwork drawn on the cards! This card game does not have deck building aspects, so it is an easy game to pick up and play with your friends.

—description from the designer

House Rules is a print and play party game where you make the rules!Take turns racing around the board, drawing cards with rules on them and collecting Star Tokens. One turn you might get a Board Rule that advances you three spaces. On your next you might get a Player Rule telling you to:


 Win a 10 second round of Charades or return to your last space
 Tweet to your secret crush or lose a Star Token
 Sketch a player in under 30 seconds AND get their approval
 Break into teams of two, have one player pick a secret word and get the other to answer it - the first team to guess their word wins Star Tokens


Everything you need to play is included in the download. Just print and play!

—description from the designer

Freight Wars is a 2-3 player game where you can procedurally generate your game tiles before you print them, giving you a completely unique game set. You are a Victorian industrialist who is looking to build a transportation network. You can do this by placing roads, rivers, or railways to connect towns to other places, as well as block off the routes of your opponents.

First, you must choose which mode of transportation each player should use. One should use roads, one rivers, the other should use trains. Then, you must shuffle the cards and hand them out to various players. Each player should get a town card, as well as two other cards dealt to them.

Players must place tiles so that the modes of transportation connect to the tiles already placed on the table. These tiles will need to match up for every mode of transportation to be placed, then the player will be able to draw another tile from the deck, so they always have three cards. Players can also skip a turn by discarding all of their tiles to draw a new hand.

After all of the tiles are placed, players must count up how many connections they have between towns. There are different points depending on how well the transport links are between different places. This can be seen in more detail in the rules of the game.
—description from the designer

This print-and-play game has an unusual distribution method - players download a Windows executable program which generates random tiles for printing. Once printed, the tiles are used for traditional tabletop play. Because the tiles are programmatically generated with randomization, no two sets will be exactly the same.

—user summary

Finally, your search for an authentic all-you-can-eat meat-themed dice game ends here!

Meat Sweats: (noun) a condition of profuse sweating due to the over-consumption of meat protein combined with elevated levels of adrenaline in the human body.

Each player is a meat-loving chef participating in the "International Shweaty Awards" - an annual competition for chefs by chefs. Chefs travel the world competing to be the best among their peers. 
 The chef that both serves and consumes the most delicious meats receives the coveted "Golden Shweaty" trophy.

Each player gets one "Craving die" for visiting the other chefs' restaurants. The Craving dice have various meats available on each face; these dice are rolled simultaneously to determine the meat the visiting chefs crave for the current course: Chicken (1 pt), Double Chicken (2 pts), Sausage(2 pts), Sausage (2 pts), or Steak (3 pts). The final side of the craving die depicts the infamous "Meat Sweats." Visiting chefs furiously roll their die to (potentially) request a better meat before the next course is served; others stop rolling to avoid a chance at getting the meat sweats (gaining 0 points).

The active player each round takes on the role of a Chef in his/her own restaurant. The active chef rolls 5 "Chef dice" when the other players are ready to be served. Only one type of meat (chicken, sausage, or steak) may be delivered each round, chosen by the active chef from among the available meats rolled. As the active chef rolls, some dice will come up as empty trays (no meat), which may not be rerolled. The active chef receives points for all meats served each course until the other players have eaten all the meat in the restaurant. Then the active chef role passes to the next player and all other competing chefs travel to the new active chef's restaurant. The game ends when all players have been the active chef and the final chef runs out of meat.

Short, light game for 3 to 8 players.

—description from the publisher

A simple cardgame based on a Dutch comedy series.

Players have to match numbers or colors to the discard pile. The first to have an empty hand wins the game. Some cards instruct players to take more cards or skip turns.

—user summary

British vs Pirates Volume 2 is a standalone expansion to the successfully Kickstartered game, British vs Pirates. This new game features 2 new factions "French/Buccaneers", new game modes, new miniatures and a lot more. Looking for a ship combat game set during the Golden Age of Piracy? Look no further, British vs Pirates.

—description from the designer

link.value: British vs Pirates: Volume 2 – South Sea Alliance

item.description: åè¬ŽåµæŽ¢ (Mystery Detective) is a fast-paced competitive logical deduction game for 3-8 players. A suspect, a motive, a weapon, and a location are chosen at random from a deck of cards, then players take turns interrogating each other for information about each of the aspects of the crime (by taking a card of the chosen type from another detective). When one player thinks they have the solution, they compare their answer with the hidden cards. If they are correct, they win! However, if any part of their answer is incorrect, the game continues and the foolish detective is eliminated.

item.description:
Pocket Skirmish is a fast-paced tactical card game for 2 players, in which you assume control over 3 units on a randomly generated map. With tactics and luck, you achieve victory by defeating all of your opponent's units!

—description from the publisher

name.value: ゲット★スイートラブ (Get★Sweet Love)

item.description:
User summary
ã‚²ãƒƒãƒˆâ˜…ã‚¹ã‚¤ãƒ¼ãƒˆãƒ©ãƒ– (Getâ˜…Sweet Love) is a Japanese card game of match-making, but with somewhat adult themes and language.

In the game, players are dealt hand cards and draw and play more cards through the game. There are four female character cards dealt face up on the table, and the players are girl-chasers, competing to win the 'best' one. But which woman is best is only determined at the finish.

During the game, players play hand cards against their chosen targets. These attribute cards have positive values for virtues, and negative values for bad behaviour. Some cards are played face-up, some face-down, so there is a strong element of bluffing in the game. Some attribute cards alter the rules as they are played.

The game is very social and encourages table talk about the good or bad attributes. For example, during game play, players will talk up the virtues of one girl, and talk down the vices of another. "She is Born Rich! That's 6 points! I'm after her." "But she's also a Money-Waster. -8 points. Are you sure you want her? hehehe."
"You know what? This girl is so Gentle and Kind and worth 8 points!" "Poor you. You might have not known, but actually, she is a B*tch. -6 points!" "Oh no, she's a B*tch and also likes Kinky Sex? Oh my oh my..."

Players also put secret tokens on the female cards, to show their likes or dislikes. After the cards have been played, the players must 'Express Love' by simultaneously pointing at the woman they chose. If only player chooses one woman, they get her. If more than player points at one woman, the player with the highest token wins her.

Then all the attribute cards are flipped and the value of the different women is calculated. The player who picked the best woman, wins!

There are two Versions of the game, this original edition is themed on men trying to get the best girlfriend. There is another edition with the genders swapped, and the women are trying to get the best boyfriend - ã‚²ãƒƒãƒˆâ˜…ã‚¹ãƒžãƒ¼ãƒˆãƒ©ãƒ– (Getâ˜…Smart Love). Whilst the games are very similar, there are differences in the special cards which affect the gameplay. With both editions, you can combine and play an 8 player game.

The game name has a couple of twists. The English name can be abbreviated to Geâ˜…S Love, which for Japanese readers equates to 'guess love', trying to guess which girl to choose. But the name ã‚²ã‚¹ãƒ©ãƒ– in Japanese, has the word ã‚²ã‚¹ in it, which is used in many vulgar or even obscene words in Japanese. So the publisher is deliberately signalling to buyers that the game is for adults but still sociable, since the girl-chasers will be nice to some girls, and not so nice to others. This version has gone through ten reprints in Japan and always draws a crowd at game shows, with its risque design (by Japanese standards).

Publisher's summary

link.value: しらたまゲームズ (Shiratama Games)

item.description:
The players have to drive their racing cars from start to finish. Movement is determined by a standard die (1-6) and a color die. The result of the color die decides which car is to be moved. So each player rolls for all players in the game. On illustrated spaces, events hinder or benefit the player. The first player to reach space 76 wins the game.

—user summary

The players have to move their token from start to finish. The token have holes in their center, which are used to move the token with a stick (lance). Movement is determined by 40 small cards with letters on them. The cards are used to form the words "Ruck" and "Zuck". The players start with 3 cards, lying open in front of them. Every turn the player draws a card. As soon as he can form one of the two words the player has to move his token accordingly. "Ruck" means forward and "Zuck" means backward. The number of spaces is equal to the number of cards used to form the word (2-4). If a player moves his token onto a green space, he may move forward to the next green space. A red space means the player has to move backward to the last red space.
The first player to reach the finish wins the game.

Building a Better Monster pits players against each other as Mad Scientists competing to be the first to build a unique creature and bring it to life. When not acting as the Mad Scientist, you take on the role of Angry Villagers trying to work together to stop the current Mad Scientist's work.

The game plays using one standard 6-sided die to determine what twisted blueprints they’ve jotted down from fever-dreams and insane visions, as well as 6 custom Mad Scientist dice to determine what building blocks they’ve managed to collect from local cemeteries, mortuaries, hospitals, or prisons. Each scientist uses these materials to make their twisted schematics a reality. With the help of their faithful lab assistants and the occasional pack of ghouls at their summons, the madness is contagious. The Angry Villagers have their own set of 6 custom dice to determine their actions for the night. Will they storm the lab with a Pitchfork or Fire? Will they decide to cut off the Electricity instead? Maybe some will sleep through the night or decide to go Grave Robbing instead to use for their own creations.

—description from the publisher

In Paolo Tortellini players collect sets of foods to win. Each player is dealt 5 cards and draws one additional one each round, trying to get two sets of three cards each.

Essentially, it's a children's version of Rommé where you have to collect two sets of three cards each out of 8 sets of 4 cards.

Kagami is a one to four player solo or cooperative abstract game in which players attempt to mirror two sides of an eight by eight board or four quadrants for a more challenging experience and more players. The game is played without verbal communication. Players score based on the type and number of stones perfectly matched on the board.

link.value: しらたまゲームズ (Shiratama Games)

name.value: クエストREクエスト (Quest Re quest)

link.value: しらたまゲームズ (Shiratama Games)

item.description:
You are the founder of a new village during the middle ages, in the years after a great plague. The loss of so many people has created big problems for the survivors. Many of the people the villagers used to depend on for essential things like food, shelter and clothes are gone. Craftsmen find themselves without suppliers of raw materials, traders have lost their customers and many have lost their farms and workshops as they escaped the plague.

The roads are full of refugees seeking a new beginning. They come to you, hoping to settle down on your land and make a living. Your grain farm is the ideal starting point for a village, reliably providing food for many people. You must choose wisely who you allow to settle with you, as your food and resources are limited.

The people on the road have valuable and unique skills, but they all in turn rely on other people with very specific crafts to be able to work. Raw materials, tools and services must be provided by other people from the road.

If you manage to find people that can work together to make a profit, while increasing your food surplus and capacity for building new houses, your village will be prosperous.

The game comes with a solo mode where a lone village strives to prosper in spite of the dreaded Countess and her evil machinations.

—description from the publisher

item.description:
Catacombs Monster Pit is a bluffing / deduction game with a twist. You are a hero trying to defeat the most monsters in the catacomb. Players take turns assuming the role of a monster, who must try to hunt the heroes. As a hero, your goal is to capture the most reward tokens by assisting your teammates defeat the monster, but also be the one who plays the winning Combat card (bluffing if necessary!). At the end of the game, the hero with the most points wins!

—description from the publisher

name.value: Rick and Morty: The Ricks Must Be Crazy Multiverse Game

item.description:
Rick and Morty: The Ricks Must Be Crazy Multiverse Game is an engine-building game (of sorts) that takes place in the four locations, a.k.a. "'verses", from the popular Rick and Morty episode "The Ricks Must Be Crazy": the Rickverse, Microverse, Miniverse, and Teenyverse. Due to time dilation and other pseudo-scientific malarkey, the lower you travel in the 'verses, the greater number of actions you have each round — but some of those lower 'verses are a bit primitive, so the contraptions you build to use all that sweet power on might not work that well!

During your turn, you spend your actions to build power supplies and contraptions, and you possibly move to a new 'verse to take advantage of some excess power there. At the end of each round, the power generates from the bottom 'verse up, and players can use that power as it travels from 'verse to 'verse to play one-shot abilities, use character abilities, and power-up their contraptions. Player order matters in each 'verse, so hopefully your opponents left you some power to use!

—description from the publisher

item.description:
Young Jacob Marley is a game of Victorian moneylending. You and your fellow clerks are newly enlisted in the service of the famous Jacob Marley. Your task is to earn the maximum profit by lending Marley's money to the citizens and businesses of London. You hope that by doing so, you might catch young Marley's eye and earn his undying friendship. You have a feeling this might come in handy one day...

Young Jacob Marley is a significant retooling of the classic game Jacob Marley, Esquire, which is also a game of cutthroat money lending in Victorian London. Imagine that.

Chrono-Mots is a cooperative game of letters with original, simple, and fast mechanisms. Players play together against the game by trying to validate as many words as possible before the letter pile is exhausted. It is therefore a question of using letters well and, above all, of saving them.

So how many words do you think you will find? It will take more than thirty words to be considered a team of geniuses.

 -info provided by publisher (Translated)
